name: NPR
text: At least 13 people were killed in a stampede at a nightclub in Peru when they tried to escape police who showed up to enforce COVID-19 restrictions on such gatherings. https://t.co/drpdNt6u50

name: NPR
text: Justin Townes Earle, the award-winning singer-songwriter and son of Steve Earle, has died. He was 38. https://t.co/TAivGGZfPH

name: NPR
text: Since a 2018 investigation by NPR led an overhaul of the troubled TEACH Grant program, the Education Department says more than 6,500 teachers have had nearly $44 million in unfair student debts turned back into grants. https://t.co/vJtWhDqA2n

name: NPR
text:
The House approved a bill to:

• infuse $25 billion into USPS
• block any service or operations changes to USPS until at least January
• require USPS to prioritize delivery of all election-related mail
  
But it's unlikely to advance through the Senate.
https://t.co/d37P39jCh5

name: NPR
text: A Black man was in serious condition after being shot several times by a police officer in Kenosha, Wisc., as authorities responded to a domestic situation, in a scene that was caught on video. https://t.co/4pLPvPYu2a

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge on Thursday dismissed President Trump's latest attempt to block a subpoena for his tax records from Manhattan's district attorney.
https://t.co/jOP7jSSuKq

name: NPR
text:
Nearly 40% of voters in North Carolina are under 40. They make up its most racially diverse voting bloc. Several who spoke to NPR said their desire to defeat Trump outweighs their reservations about Biden.

"Trump got to go, that's all I know," one says.  
https://t.co/xGlE6hzDbm

name: NPR
text:
"Donald Trump not only has a higher percentage of political ambassadors, but has a higher percentage of ambassadors who don't seem to be temperamentally or intellectually suited for the work," says a former U.S. diplomat.
https://t.co/C6DoIHtLkj

name: NPR
text:
A lot of the nuts and bolts of voting in the U.S. can feel like obstacles: registration, showing up at the right polling place, getting time off work to vote. 

@npritsbeenamin Sam Sanders talks with historian Martha S. Jones. https://t.co/rCeS2jMO6L https://t.co/1sNjJM8Qby

name: NPR
text:
An extraordinarily high number of ballots — more than 550,000 — have been rejected in this year's presidential primaries, an NPR analysis finds.

That's far more than the 318,728 ballots rejected in the 2016 general election.
 https://t.co/wFgLE4Vwod

name: NPR
text:
1) Think of a place on earth with a four-word name
2) Take the third word
3) Advance 3 of its letters to the next letter of the alphabet (so A would become B, B would be come C, etc.)
4) You'll get the fourth word in the name. 

What place is this? https://t.co/BuieGwOA6R

name: NPR
text:
In a norm-breaking move criticized by ethics experts, President Trump will deliver his acceptance speech from the White House lawn. 

Ahead of the Republican National Convention, here are 5 questions to note:
https://t.co/vxOcQy2Vu7

name: NPR
text: The redwoods and condors will likely survive the wildfires raging in California, biologists say. The larger question is whether ecosystems can fully bounce back after extreme fires given that the climate change can make recovery difficult. https://t.co/HaHYKgtEjU

name: NPR
text:
Doctors say even when taken off ventilators, some COVID-19 patients remain unconscious for days, weeks or longer. 

They worry medical teams are not waiting long enough for patients to awaken before removing life support.
https://t.co/yAfWzojasQ

name: NPR
text: WATCH LIVE: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy appears before the House Oversight Committee, amid growing concerns that changes made under his leadership could jeopardize the Postal Service’s ability to serve customers. https://t.co/o1Ssf1gYLn

name: NPR
text:
Here are best practices to help you socialize safely — whether you're isolating at home or an essential worker on the job.
https://t.co/uENLwP2bK7

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprpolitics: Delegates to the Republican National Convention in Charlotte have formalized the re-nomination of Mike Pence for vice president of the United States. 

The convention will now proceed to the presidential nomination. Follow the latest developments here: https://t.co/R2uiI5Ig9Q

name: NPR
text: Tests show Alexei Navalny — one of Russian President Vladimir Putin's most prominent critics — was poisoned by a substance that disrupts the nervous system, according to the German doctors treating him. https://t.co/iXbEmwCCEe

name: NPR
text:
President Trump made a surprise visit to Charlotte to fire up the delegates gathered at the Republican National Convention.

"This is the most important election in the history of our country," he said. 
https://t.co/at4xW3qKYS

name: NPR
text:
For more than 50 years, the Somali sengi, a relative of aardvarks and elephants, was thought to be a lost species. 

Turns out, it wasn't. The small mammal was recently spotted not in Somalia — but in neighboring Djibouti.
https://t.co/jEDVb9W0xU

name: NPR
text: RT @WUWMradio: The Kenosha County Sheriff’s Department announced an 8 p.m. curfew for the second night in a row Monday. The curfew follows unrest in Kenosha after the police shooting of Jacob Blake Sunday. The curfew will be enforced until 7 a.m. Tuesday. https://t.co/BsH6hiKppB

name: NPR
text: TikTok has filed a federal lawsuit against the Trump administration arguing that the president's executive order banning the popular app in the U.S. is unconstitutional and should be blocked from taking effect. https://t.co/W0PzVtmzUa

name: NPR
text:
Polls suggest white seniors are leaning toward Biden, but some in battleground states tell NPR they're sticking with Trump. 

"Even though his character might be bad, he is supporting religious freedom, religious rights, right to life,” one says. https://t.co/8IJRxMRPkN

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: Jerry Falwell, Jr. has officially resigned as president of Liberty University after a series of controvers… https://t.co/UBPYYZfFJZ

name: NPR
text: Falwell's departure comes on the heels of a Reuters investigation in which Falwell's former business partner claime… https://t.co/VpNf7XxYsf

name: NPR
text: RT @lesommer: Back in Feb, I covered a fire that did not involve destruction and stress. California's Native American tribes are restoring cultural burning and are beginning to partner with govt to put more "good fire" on the land - a key step to reducing extreme fires. https://t.co/uptdNnY7sJ

name: NPR
text: Gov. Tony Evers is calling the Wisconsin Legislature into a special session next week to take up a package of bills on police accountability, transparency, and use of force. The response comes a day after Kenosha police shot a Black man multiple times. https://t.co/4IruckoWdl

name: NPR
text:
Falwell has faced multiple controversies in recent years — including questionable business dealings, accusations of racial insensitivity, and allegations of other behavior considered inappropriate for the head of a conservative religious institution.
https://t.co/YkMZQ6CDt3

name: NPR
text:
A century ago, California banned Native American tribes from their traditional practice of controlled burns. 

Now, officials say reducing the risk of wildfires means restoring "good fire" —  much like the state's tribes once did.
https://t.co/YGpdvrrbi1

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: Presenting @tameimpala like you've never heard it before: Watch Kevin Parker perform a Tiny Desk (home) concert on his "Tame Impala Soundsystem." https://t.co/wCFxxnQx6z
